description.narrative: Swedish Radio Media Development Organisation will support five regional radio stations under Rwanda Broadcasting Agency and their youth station in Kigali as well as four independent community radios, all in their given mandates. SR MDO will complete what they had to suspend 2015 upon Sidas termination of agreement with IWPR in Rwanda as the organisation was denied the right to register. The agreement with IWPR is cancelled.

Syftet är att bidra till att stärka fem regionala public service radiostationer och en station för unga via Rwanda Broadcasting Agency samt fyra oberoende byradiostationer i Rwanda genom coaching av Sveriges Radio Media Development Organisation (SR MDO). Radio stationerna ska stärkas i den uppgift de är ålagda att genomföra. SR MDO kommer att slutföra vad de påbörjade 2015 inom ett större mediaprogram som ej kunde slutföras då avtalspartnern, IWPR, förlorade sin registrering i landet. Avtalet med IWPR är nu uppsagt.

The overall objective has been to contribute to strengthened freedom of expression in Rwanda and support a clear role of broadcasting media as a tool of democracy and empowerment of the citizens. Firstly, during the 1,5 year long project the Swedish Radio Media Development Organisation (SR-MDO) aimed at contributing to the transformation of Rwanda Broadcasting Agency’s regional radio stations into Public Service Radios, delivering more professional programming, news and current affairs programmes in line with International Journalistic Standards and Public Service Broadcasting Values.Secondly, RBA’s Magic FM in Kigali established as a station for urban youth delivering programs and content according to Public Service Broadcasting Values. Thirdly the project aimed at supporting a five year strategic plan for RBA to be developed, including clarity and commitment at Board and Executive level regarding role of Public Service Broadcasting in Rwanda and clarity for the boards and the executive of their role and responsibility and having established procedures and policies for good.

description.narrative: • At regional level RBA has strengthened both journalistic and editorial skills e.g. the reporters have started putting the people first in a bottom-up approach instead of the top-down that was practiced before. This has allowed more citizen voices to be heard on the radio. Listeners' participation has also increased thanks to more focus on audience engagement through social media and live reporting on-site. • Three phases of on-the-job training have been carried out at the regional stations since 2014. The five regional station managers have been trained in leadership and management to improve journalistic quality and practice. Rwandan journalists have also worked alongside Swedish journalists to enhance production skills, especially in news. • Each reporter at regional level now have their own recording device, compared to previously when each team shared 2-3 recorders. This has improved the overall quality of the production, as the reporters have more time to talk to people and be more flexible with their approach. This has also boosted creativity and built confidence and pride among the reporters. • The technical standard of the regional radio stations have improved, thanks to capacity building and better technical equipment. • Magic FM has been established as a youth-centred radio station. Its format has been tailored with input from a range of activities, such as audience research, improved skills and social media. Magic FM is assessed as holding a stronger position among young listeners today compared to 2014. • Five local marketing plans have been completed, including plans for implementation. • The board and senior management of RBA have completed their first own strategic plan, including values, role and responsibility.
